title: Between 8 March 2022 and 22 April 2022, will the S&P 500 Index close at an all-time high?
preds: Not much left to say about this one.
Well, I suppose it's sorta cheating that I'm updating my forecast the day before the question closes.  But I couldn't leave it at 1%, so now it's 0%.

I am first seeing this question on 4/20/2022. With 2 days left before the close, I am trying to estimate the probability of a roughly 8% jump in price within 2 days. I tried looking at this 2 ways: I would really like to put this as a 1/2000 event, but barring that I will round it to a 0%.

Updating forecast from last month.  Forecast was set at 10% then.  Current forecast is set  at 1%, because we can only do whole numbers.  Based on an analysis of S&P 500 closing prices. Data source: FRED (https://fred.stlouisfed.org/).
April 22 is in three days. So, it is very unlikely for the S&P to gain 400 points in that period.
it is firmly off the table at this point
Close to no chance to rise this week.
With such little time left, not likely
<1% - would require a 10% increase in a week
Extremely unlikely with ongoing high inflation readings and still several % point below the previous all time high.

Given all of the factors weighing on stock values, their historically high price-to-earnings numbers, inverted treasurioes, and the geo-political instabilty created by the war in Ukraine, this simply won't happen.
Crazy things can happen - but this does not appear likely anymore.  We are not heading in a good direction with the war.
Not likely to get there by 22 April at this point

Today's losses mean that a gain somewhere in the ballpark of 9% would be needed over the remaining 7 trading days, and that's just not likely.

I think I'm going to have a terrible score on this forecast. I thought it was much more likely that the S&P500 would go up more in the forecast period. It's not over 'til it's over, but it's not looking good.

A jump of 400 points in 11 days is certainly possible. But with all stocks dropping a bit at the moment and no economic outlooks looking good it doesn’t feel like the right time.  Plus Easter weekend will take a couple of trading days out (I assume they close?!  Didn’t check that)

Odds of a 9% increase in 8 days are <1% on a random walk by my possibly suspect math. As far as I can tell there isn't a historical precedent for it except during extreme market crashes (which we aren't in the middle of)

Given passage of time and recent market action I will revise this lower. Appears the market's relief rally is taking a much needed break and I doubt we have the buying power to rally >10% in 10 days or so. Volumes down heading into Easter...
Closing of the question coming soon, Easter holidays also likely to limit activity to a degree and as price is lowering limited possibility for the price to rise again, let alone to an all time high

Historically - apparently - SP500 has set all time highs only on 5% of trading days and there are only 9 days left. Currently there is almost no clear trend of bounce back from 2022 Q1 decline. Creatively interpreting very volatile march/April moves, maybe max 6% very optimistically. No major announcements will work in favour of better odds. Might update though!
9 days left, not enough time. A random walk puts it at ~2-3% but all fundamentals and sentiment is pointing to a bear market
Appears much less likely now but not totally unlikely.  Will keep tracking and updating.
Stocks rebounded today after back-to-back losing sessions as investors assessed the Federal Reserve’s plans to tighten monetary policy and combat inflation.
Overcorrecting slightly, having left this in the 30s for last week or so.
10 market days left and needs to rise 6%
Between rapid inflation and the war in Ukraine, this seems highly unlikely.

As of writing this forecast the S&P is sitting at ~$4,450, or about ~7% below its ATH of ~$4800 with 11 trading days left after today and the dead line. This averages to a daily return of ~0.64% or, an annualized return of ~161% over the remaining period. With the NASDAQ rally having naturally running out of steam as it retraced back to near it's 100 and 200 day SMAs around $14750, we have seen the S&P follow suite. If the NASDAQ continues to trade sideways for the next couple days as the recent gains off the bottom are digested it is difficult to see what other sector can take the lead to drive the S&P higher. If this sideways trading is translated to the S&P (Which baring another sector taking over significant leadership seems likely if the NASDAQ continues to consolidate) then what is already a difficult amount of ground to make up in such a short time becomes even harder. While I still believe new ATHs are coming before lower lows; it seems clear at this time that there is too little time, with too much ground to make up and too many downward pressure to see that happening before the deadline. I am leaving a 2% (1:50) margin of error to account for some major news event causing the NASDAQ to gap up and continue it's recent rally, driving the S&P higher with it.
two weeks to go, and there's still a few hundred points to climb. Inflation is still pretty high
The short time frame is really reducing the chances since the target is still quite far.
The current international situation does not have a positive outlook for the next month.
With the prevailing uncertainty in markets, this is still unlikely so reinforcing at 20% level.
Still fluctations that are high.  Rebound on the March loss maybe hit its max.  Will going down a bit more.

with 18 days remaining in the question and the S&P 500 still trailing the all-time high by 236 - it would need to average an increase of 13 points per day consistently...it is on an upward trend right now - i don't know if it will consistently gain that much

Only 14 trading days remaining, Monte Carlo gives between 10% and 18% using daily shifts over the past year or since November 1 2021 respectively, converting implied volatility in SPX options on Yahoo to probability gives 2.4%. There is an upward trend, but the timeline is very short at this point and every indication I can find puts a pretty low chance. I'm mentally prepared to eat this forecast when some random big jump or streak occurs, but its hard to say that's likely.

Closed at 4,545.86, +15.45 (0.34%) on Friday. All time high is 4,818.62
Goldman Sachs revised the S&P to 4,700 for the year - from 4,900, initial target 5,100.

"Markets have had a rollercoaster quarter due to Russia's invasion of Ukraine, volatile commodities prices and the U.S. Federal Reserve starting to hike interest rates." Inflation continues at record levels, but employment numbers are not disappointing, Fed Res hikes are on schedule, the pandemic is for now under control and most places in the US are in full reopening. The Biden admin plans to release millions of barrels of oil from its reserves to address hike in oil prices. 
So, what could go wrong in the next 2-3 weeks or what can keep propelling the S&P? An escalation caused by the Russian invasion of Ukraine that would cause the war to spill outside Ukraine? Would seem that is something that is being actively prevented. 
A major cyber attack on the US or Europe? Vix indicators are more positive and the S&P has kept rising for the past 3 weeks. The index rose +216.99 (5.01%) in the past month so the question is if it can keep that up and then some for the next 3 weeks. Given the risks and uncertainty in geopolitical environment, I would err in the side of caution, for now, and assume it will be steady but will fall short of an all time high.

It really comes down to whether other portions of the supply chain can be stabilized in between the periods of non-equilibrium to offset core consumer pricing enough to ease overall fears (especially among retail investors); Markets are so reactive and over-reactive (i.e., retail investors buying on dips) it is difficult for me to perceive a clear direction of sentiment at this time (I'm sure that is not the case for hedge fun managers trying to steer these markets).
About the same odds of a truce between Russia and Ukraine.
Russia/ Ukraine situation has calmed down so this be less likely.
The price has moved away from the target today.

US stock markets are going to post the first losing quarter in q12022 for two years. Some people may call it selling streak. I'd call it "normalization". Negative momentum may be sustained for up to two more weeks amid little to no tangible progress in peace negotiations and Russia's threat of trying to kill off the European economies in case Russia will not be reimbursed for energy deliveries in Russian ruble from tomorrow.

Recalibrating after recent rally in the SPX. Feels like a bear-market rally a bit so I'm fading the exuberence given the chance of a re-escalation of the Ukraine/Russia crisis, or a spiraling in inflation numbers. Still doubt we breach new highs, but at this point it's a tighter distance to cover so can't rule it out.
Continued rise back towards levels that could see it top the previous mark

I have no idea how inflation or the Ukraine war will affect the S&P500, so I used a Monte Carlo model on S&P500 close prices to get a base rate. I fit a normal distribution to close prices for the last 10 years. Then, 1000 times, I randomly sampled percentage yields from the normal distribution 17 times for the 17 business days until the end. Then, I took the maximum of the 17 values for each of the 1000 trials, and 40% of them were > the ATH (ie 40% of cases had at least one close price > the current ATH). If you only take the final value at COB on 22 April, the model says 26% (the current crowd forecast). Stock yields are not quite normal, but I don't currently have the tools to fit, say, an alpha-stable distribution to the yields, so I'll leave it at 40%.

Else resistance is at 4649, 4697 - so has to cross this before chances for going above ATH go up. Some recession indicator can pull it own. Currently >50% indicators on SELL, so further rally is limited. But recent jump required probability upgrade from 25 to 40.

The closing level moved nearer to the target.

The question here is whether the S&P will top its Jan. 3 high of $4796 before 22 April. The previous trend was about $64/month, and we're currently at $4602. So- we'd have to increase about $190 over the next three weeks or so. We've actually recently just had a jump like that - about $250 in the three days following March 14. I have to imagine that investor sentiment will improve a bit on improved Russia news. I guess I still think this is less likely than more, but I'll plant a flag here.

As of writing this forecast the S&P is sitting at ~$4600,  ~4% shy of it all time high of ~$4800 with 18 trading days after today between now and the deadline. This averages out to a daily return of ~0.22% or an annualized return of ~55% over the period in question. At this point I feel pretty comfortable asserting that the bottom is in on the S&P correction and NASDAQ bear market. It seems clear the indices have rebounded off their low and had a pretty significant relief rally in the recent week or two. This bottom appears to have happened in tandem with peak fear around the FED raising rates at the March meeting and the conflict in Ukraine. Both of which the market seems to be coming to terms with; and it seems it was not as bad as the market had priced in. I would expect both indices to reach a new ATH before a lower low at this point. The question in my mind is then if the recovery will occur fast enough for the new ATH to occur before the deadline. While 4% is certainly within reason if the NASDAQ recovery continues at it current rates, I would expect the NASDAQ rally to hit a little bit of a wall as it approaches it's 100 Day SMA and 200 Day SMA around ~14750. If there is some catalyst (Resolution to Ukraine crisis, inflation naturally reverting to more normal historic level, significant earnings surprises to the upside, etc.) than I think the indices easily push through this level and should comfortably hit the ATH before the deadline. That said, if we do not get any significant news I see the NASDAQ rally slowing naturally. If Tech stalls, then I think it would be difficult for the S&P to continue it's rise unless there is significantly more juice to squeeze out of the energy trade that has been ongoing this year. With how high global oil prices have been this also seems pretty unlikely to me. While it is certainly within the realm of possibility, I think we still need one really good piece of good new to serve as a catalyst to overcome the key price levels we are approaching. If this does not happen then I think we trade sideways for a while. Meaning while I think ATHs are coming, without that spark I don't think we hit them before the deadline. I am giving this one a coin flips probability at this point.

It's at about 4610 this morning as I write this and even touched 4625 earlier. It closed yesterday at 4575.52. About 187 (4.1%) to go to reach a new all-time high (previous 4,796.56), in almost 19 remaining trading days. The index closed at 4170.7 on March 8; it is up about 439 (10.5%) in the just over 14 trading days since then. The market is generally trending upward, perhaps over inflation and improving news about Ukraine. Slightly increasing my forecast. Since the launch of this question on March 15, the crowd forecast has moved from 1% (to 0%) to 19% currently. During this period, the S&P500 closing has moved from 4262.45, 534.11 (12.5%) away from the all-time high, to 4575.52 yesterday, 221.05 (4.8%) from the all-time high. And today, it seems to be continuing to go up. Perhaps it will close at around 4% from the all-time high. Given that this gap has gone from 12.5% to ~4% - it has been cut to 1/3 of its starting value - it is surprising to me that the crowd forecast has not moved higher than 19%.
Using a one touch model of closing prices with volatility based on VIX gave 38%.  Historic vol gave 26%.
It is already picked up a lot of the previous correction.  The market still seems high considering all the uncertainty. I have been wrong before though.

It closed today at 4575.52. 221.05 (4.8%) to go to reach a new all-time high, in 19 remaining trading days. The index closed at 4170.7 on March 8; it is up 404.82 (9.7%) in the 14 trading days since then. The market is generally trending upward, perhaps over inflation and improving news about Ukraine. I see this increase as the market rebounding from fears about Ukraine, plus growing from increasing investment because of inflation. Slightly increasing my forecast.
Market is not a fan of instability, I will adjust if there is a Russian coup d'etat.

Adjusting initial, over-confident “0%” forecast based on arguments in recent post by @belikewater: 
https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1423303
The short remaining timeframe, however, makes me still think that a new all time high is much less likely than not to happen.

The market is generally going up, probably at least in part as a result of inflation and improving news out of Ukraine. I expect this trend to continue. The index reached over 4540 twice this week, including at closing today at 4543.06. The all-time highest closing value was 4,796.56 on Monday, January 3, 2022. 253.50 remaining to go to reach 4796.56 (5.6%). It has gone up 369.95 (8.9%) since closing at 4173.11 on March 14, in just 9 trading days. 20 more trading days remain. I expect that when March's inflation numbers come in, that will help the market even a bit further. I don't expect the market to go straight up, of course, but it is certainly rebounding from fears about Ukraine pretty quickly.
-1 from 20% to closer hug the forecasts of @boxerjaime, @DNK89, @JAVL, and @The_Fully_Clothed_Analyst, all of whom are pretty low and have good track records and/or methods overall.

My gut tells me this is 50% to 80% likely. But because (a) the crowd median is low; (b) the trend to get there has slowed in the past day (although it has been rallying pretty high the past 5 days... ~80 points per day versus the required 11.5 needed to get to the all-time high); and (c) continuity with my previous forecast.
Doubt it because: 1) China-Us tensions still like an estranged marriage, 2) fear of russo gov cyber attacks.   Perhaps because: 1) mid term elections, 2) interest rate increases.

Like the article @Eolienne and used "Stocks historically have weathered rate-hike cycles fairly well. Since 1983, the S&P 500 has returned an average of 5.3% in the six months following the first Fed rate rise of a cycle, data from UBS showed." to form the basis of why its unlikely to close at an all time high in a month.  Article - https://www.reuters.com/business/finance/wall-st-week-ahead-after-sizzling-rebound-investors-weigh-whether-stocks-have-2022-03-19/

My prior is that it is unlikely, based on current position and usual growth rates.  Never forecast with certainty, especially when markets are involved, so my question I'm trying to answer is how unlikely.  What could make the markets exhibit incredible growth?  I'm having difficulty picturing anything that could- even an ending to the war in Ukraine would probably not be sufficient.  Opening up of exchange with a country like Venezuela or Iran would still probably not be enough, even if the war were ended.  Unexpected good news on inflation could make a difference, if it were really good news.  That seems very unlikely.  So now I've talked myself into an 8% yes.  Anything less seems TOO certain.

The S&P is unlikely to close at an all-time high while there's still so much uncertainty.  With the US role in Ukraine still developing and our relations with Russia and China at an all-time low, the markets tend to respond with fluctuations, movement of capital to safer investments, and sell-offs.  Domestic inflation is also leading to higher interest rates that will affect the housing markets and any company related to real property and lending.

15% growth in just over a month would be very hard to do I imagine. Without digging into the data I suspect that the base rate for this is very low. I'm leaving a 5% chance due to perceived increase in volatility, which the VIX index confirms as well.

Last 48 months of monthly returns only exceed this threshold 1 time (very close one other month).  While some bounce back could be expected as investors gain clarity on countries responses to Russia's invasion and subsequent effects on raw material prices, my forecast stays in line with the past historical data.

Outside view:
There are 28 trading days between now and 22nd April. I took all the closing price data of the S&P500 over the last 10 years (max I could download) Current ATH: 4796.56
Last Price: 4262.45
% Increase required to reach ATH: 13.00 Total number of 28 day intervals to analyse: 2488 Number of times the price has increased by the % required to reach ATH: 16
Number of times the price has changed by the abs % required to reach ATH: 37
Average percentage change between 28 working days: 1.3754019292604502
Average absolute percentage change between 28 working days: 3.4662379421221865
Median percentage change between 28 working days: 2.0
Median absolute percentage change between 28 working days: 3.0 Using mostly that first data point - number of times the price has increased by the % required to reach ATH - we can see that in the chance of that increase occuring in any given timeframe is miniscule (roughly 0.5%). Inside View:
Market is very volatile at the moment, but good news (e.g. war ending) will probably not take it to it's ATH which was reached at the start of the year. I think the outside view informs well and this is pretty much guaranteed to not happen.

Historically, this is not the time for big rallies. This event would require a significant breakout from a technical perspective. However, a possibility for positive momentum remains if geopolitical pressures can be lifted and clarity about Fed actions is priced into underlying assets. Still, even in an optimistic scenario this will most likely not amount to new highs.

Would require an 11% move in ~1month which seems like a big leap. I'd have to look back and analyze how many times the S&P has made a move in the short of a time period, notwithstanding we have multiple crises ongoing at a macro level+a rising rate environment. My intuition says it's a low likelihood but I do leave 12% in the event of a significant escalation in Russia/Ukraine or a dovish shift in Fed policy
To reach all time high the rate must hit 4,850>+-
Like everyone else this seems like too large of a move up to occur in the short time horizon.
With the Ukraine war, shortages of commodities and supply chain problems plus increased prices, it seems unlikely that the Index will continue to defy gravity.
No. If anything we're headed for a correction or depression.
Uncertainty is too high with war, COVID and inflation.
A 13% gain in less than 6 weeks? It's happened twice in the past 24 months, so it's certainly possible, just very, very improbable.

Fed tightening, inflation pressuring margins, market not cheap, all tailwinds.
$226 earnings forecast for the index probably needs to be reduced. 
Bearish sentiment and US consumer balance sheet strength among the few apparent positives.
My initial forecast was not aggressive enough

Ukraine, inflation, supply chain / resource shortages and potential for another COVID comeback. I just don’t see the global business environment supporting the kind of large upward jump we’d need to see over the coming ~month.

Keeping the same rationale, but deciding that my previous forecast was too optimistic: Current price: 4,262.45
All-time High: 4,793.56
% gain to ATH: 12.5% This is definitely within reach, but I am skeptical that this will happen because I think to get that kind of gain from here you'd have to at least resolve either the Russian invasion of Ukraine and start immediately reversing sanctions, or somehow resolve inflation fears without causing a recession. Both of those are difficult problems in their own right and are impossible to resolve quickly.

As of this forecast, the S&P is sitting ~12% off of all time highs.(The largest draw down since the COVID crash) Looking at the historical chart for similar period of increase ~12% the most recent example appears to be the bounce off the lows of the COVID crash. (April 2020, ~$2500 to ~$2900 for monthly increase of ~14%). This means for this to return to all time highs we would need to have reason to believe a similar reversal is about to happen. Digging into the components a bit we can see this sell off has largely been driven by a large sell off in Mega-cap and high growth technology names. With Apple, Microsoft, Amazon, Google, Tesla, NVIDIA, Facebook, and Netflix making up ~25% of the index themselves (Companies that are all massively off their highs) it seems any chance the index has to try and recapture all time highs must involve these Mega-Cap tech stocks to rebound quickly in a return to a market wide risk-on approach.  While recent volatility to the downside would suggest market mechanics could lead to a drastic reversal (ie Derivative traders caught offside by a reversal may need to cover their shorts), this would still need to triggered by some event to clearly display the market has gotten too pessimistic on Mega-cap and Growth tech. The things I could see as a potential spark to trigger this would be one or some combination of something along the lines of:
a) Rapid resolution in the Russian-Ukrainian conflict
b) Central Banks surprising the market by keeping rates lower longer, unwinding already priced in rate increases
c) Energy markets collapsing in price, driving a rotation back out of Energy and back into Mega-cap Tech sparking a risk-on mood.
d) Rapid resolution to rising inflation
e) Escalating conflict in other countries make investment riskier and a flight to safety effect to drives money to the American markets
f) Some other major event Overall, the recent environment would seem ripe for a reversal provided with the right spark. However, there would need to be a drastic event happen very soon for the reversal to have enough time to recover the needed 12%. I certainly see several possible reasons a rally could happen, but all of these seem pretty low chance of happening fast enough for this question to resolve in time.
Some sort of hysterical rebound can't be ruled out but seems very unlikely
